Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Globally Optimized Robust Systems on Multi-Core Hardware

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The focus of this project is on designing robust multi-core systems at lowest cost that are resilient to hardware failures. It is motivated by an imminent paradigm shift in hardware design resulting from the growing problem of hardware failures in future process technologies. The central vision is to develop techniques and tools for designing hierarchical robust multi-core systems that are globally optimized across multiple abstraction layers ? circuit, architecture, runtime, and application ? without incurring the high cost of expensive redundancy techniques. An inter disciplinary approach will integrate research and education required to enable future robust systems. Because of its cross-cutting nature, the proposed research has the potential of having a major impact on future systems, enabling future technology scaling, thus making everyday lives better.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electronic systems are ubiquitous in our lives and are becoming increasingly used in systems (automobiles, medical devices, etc.) that affect our health and safety. New technologies for implementing electronics is expected to become less reliable so it is imperative that new design methodologies be developed to ensure that the systems built from emerging electronics are safe and resilient to failure. In this NSF-supported project, techniques that enable electronic systems to test themselves and localize identified failures have been developed and analyzed. The developed approach is economical in that it re-uses much of the same techniques used to test electronics at the time they are fabricated. This means that current producers of electronics (e.g., IBM, Texas Instruments, Intel, Qualcomm, etc.) can easily incorporate the test-and-diagnosis approach developed in this project into their future designs of electronic systems.

Both undergraduate and graduate students participated in this project, specifically being trained to analyze and design advanced electronic systems using the state-of-the-art tools and fabrication technologies, and to apply and develop new machine-learning algorithms. One graduate student is now employed by a US-based company, and the undergraduate students are now planning to extend their education by seeking advanced (M.S. and Ph.D.) engineering degrees. The research conducted during this project has also led to new projects that will continue to further the advancement of electronic systems.
